persona.persdescription: Sir John Falstaff is a very fat rogue with no money but many plans to get some. An old, white-bearded man with great self-esteem, he has no doubts about his attractiveness to the ladies, and intends to use this supposed seductiveness to get his hands on some ladies’ gold. Unfortunately for him he does not realize that he is not quite as much of a prize as he thinks, nor that both his targets (Mistress Page and Mistress Ford) are best friends and will show each other everything. He also does not think that his followers might ever turn on him. A great coward, Falstaff will undergo any humiliation to avoid being caught by a jealous husband, whether it is being snuck out in a laundry basket or dressing as a woman and being beaten as a witch. He is a great speaker who can talk himself out of almost any situation and enjoys the sound of his own voice to excess. Having absolutely no sense of morality, he has no qualms about conning people, beating up people who get in his way, and poaching another man’s deer. A drinker addicted to sack, his main purpose in life is to indulge himself, for which he needs money, the chief end of his endeavors. He is much more easily deceived than he thinks he can be, and he continues to trust the two merry wives as they make a fool of him time and again. Still, he is able to laugh at himself and recognize how well he has been served.

Master Fenton is a young, good-looking gentleman with a bit of a wild past who became very attracted to Anne Page when he discovered how rich her father is. Having spent most of his own money, he set his cap at her, but has since fallen genuinely in love with the girl. He is kind and rather too easy with his money. He has a wart above one eye.

persname.short: SHAL., ALL PAGE. AND SHAL. AND SLEN.

persona.persdescription: Justice Robert Shallow is an old and respectable man, if somewhat foolish. A Justice of the Peace, and therefore the chief official of the law in town, he is a rich man with a deer enclosure where he alone is allowed to hunt. He hopes to marry his nephew Slender to Anne Page, and does what he can to push the match further. At times he has to take over the wooing himself, as his nephew is not very adept at the job. Over eighty years old, he remembers his youth fondly, and is delighted to join in with the plot to carry Anne off during the final prank on Falstaff. He thinks himself much more canny than he actually is.

Master Frank Ford is a middle-aged, middle-class gentleman of Windsor afflicted with an almost pathological case of jealousy. Though he trusts his wife Alice with the household finances, he is convinced that she will not hesitate to cheat on him given the least opportunity, an opinion he holds of all women. He cannot understand why other husbands do not see the same risks he does about their wives. His suspicions run so deep that he is quite willing to make a fool of himself, and he disguises himself in order to try and discover via Falstaff whether he is right to be as paranoid as he is. His terror of being cuckolded pushes him into wilder and wilder behavior, and the fact that his neighbors mock him mercilessly each time he can produce no proof of his allegations does nothing to dampen him. He is not a man to do things by halves; when his wife and Mistress Page explain what has been going on, he becomes as extravagant in his apologies as he was in his jealousy. He is prejudiced against foreigners and fortune-tellers. He is a rich man, and willing to risk a fair bit of his money to find out whether his wife is faithful or not; he also buys the disguises for the children who dress as fairies.

persname.short: PAGE., ALL PAGE. AND SHAL. AND SLEN.

persona.persdescription: Master George Page is a wealthy gentleman of Windsor, married to Mistress Margaret and father of Anne and William. He is well-aware of his place in society and therefore rejects Master Fenton as a husband for his daughter, thinking him too high-born; he prefers a good, solid marriage with a rich man of Windsor, Master Slender. He finds Master Ford’s jealousy ludicrously over-the-top, and tries to calm him down, without much success. He loves and trusts his wife and is willing to follow her advice in most things, allowing her to be in charge of the family finances. Nevertheless, he tries to act behind her back to get Anne to marry Master Slender, never dreaming that Anne might deceive him and run off with her own choice of husband instead. He is a good-natured fellow who enjoys a good laugh.

William Page is the young son of Master George Page and Mistress Margaret. A schoolboy, he is better at Latin than either of his parents think, though he is not overly enthusiastic about school. Along with his schoolfellows, he dresses up as a fairy to make a mock of Falstaff.

Sir Hugh Evans is a Welsh parson and the schoolmaster of Windsor; he has not lost his very heavy accent either in English or in Latin, which is a source of much amusement to the others. A decent fellow, he tries to be a peace-broker in Windsor, though with only mixed success. He also attempts to help Slender’s suit to Anne Page, with the unfortunate effect of finding himself challenged to a duel by a choleric Frenchman. Though he tries to stiffen his backbone and go through with it, he is terrified at the idea and tries to reassure himself by singing. Evans has the typical teacher’s love of precise language, and will correct people if he catches them in error; Mistress Quickly’s mistakes and misunderstands baffle him almost completely. He is deeply concerned by Ford’s irrational behavior. Impressed by Mistress Page and Mistress Ford’s ingenuity, he is delighted to join in their final prank on Falstaff, and gets his students to play the fairies for it. Himself disguised, he is the first to press a candle-flame on Sir John.

Doctor Caius is a French physician, a short-tempered, easily offended man who is wooing Anne Page and does not wish to see anyone else moving in on her. Quick to judgment, he assumes that Evans is hoping to marry Anne himself, and immediately challenges the Welshman to a duel. Dr. Caius has an extremely heavy French accent and is not fully in command of English, which cannot be helped by the fact that his housekeeper is Mistress Quickly, herself not the best user of the language. Mistress Page supports him as Anne’s husband, and tries to arrange for him to run off with her during the final prank on Falstaff. Unfortunately for him, he is tricked by the girl herself, and ends up being married to a boy. As the local doctor and a man well-connected with the court, he is a respected citizen, despite his bad English and his choleric ways.

Host of the Garter Inn is a rather merry innkeeper who is incapable of saying anything simply and likes showing off how many words he knows. Though he enjoys mocking foreigners, he likes both Evans and Caius and does not want to see them skewer one another, though he perhaps has too much fun making fools of them to stop their duel. He is not quite cautious enough to avoid having his horses stolen from him by some conmen, and the loss of money that represents leaves him open to Fenton’s promises of payment if he arranges the young man’s secret wedding with Anne. He likes playing tricks, for instance introducing the disguised Ford to Falstaff.

Bardolph is one of Falstaff’s followers; when the fat knight can no longer afford to keep his men, he finds Bardolph a job as bartender for the Host. He is a rogue, a conman and a thief, but seems to do his new job honestly enough. He does not realize that the German guests at the inn are conmen themselves until they gallop off with the inn’s horses.

Pistol is one of Falstaff’s followers, a swaggering man who loves the sound of his own voice and is incapable of speaking like a normal human being, instead grandiloquently talking like a hammy actor in a melodrama. He is hot-tempered and seems to be always angling for a fight. He refuses to help Falstaff in his plot against the ladies of Windsor, and instead joins Nim in derailing the plan by telling Ford and Page about Falstaff’s designs on their wives. Discovering that Mistress Quickly makes a fair bit of money acting as an intermediary in love affairs, he sets his cap at her as a good way of getting the money Falstaff refuses to give him. He dresses up as Hobgoblin for the fairy scene for a chance to get some physical revenge on the knight.

Nym is one of Falstaff’s followers, and is obsessed with humors. He refuses to help Falstaff with his plans of seduction, and to revenge himself on the fat knight’s insults convinces Pistol to join him and inform Ford and Page of Falstaff’s designs on their wives. He has a very one-track mind. He is a conman, who manages to trick Slender out of an expensive chain.

Robin is Falstaff’s page, but is not the most faithful of servants. Though he brings Falstaff’s love letters to Mistress Page and Mistress Ford, he is easily convinced by them to turn traitor and lead his master into their trap, despite the fat knight’s threat of dismissing him from service if he should mention Falstaff’s planned double-dealing with the ladies. Mistress Page’s bribing him with new clothes doubtless helps. He is ambitious to be grown, and knows how to flatter a lady.
Peter Simple is Slender’s servant, an obsequious fellow much impressed by his social betters who must put up with a lot from his foolish master.
John Rugby is Dr. Caius’s servant. He is deeply intimidated by his master.

Mistress Alice Ford is a middle-aged lady of Windsor, married to Master Frank Ford. She was quite impressed by Falstaff until he sends her a love letter, at which point she begins to scorn him, and even more so when she discovers that her best friend, Mistress Page, has received exactly the same letter. She is aware that her husband is wildly jealous, and terrified at what will happen if he should discover that Falstaff is wooing her. She agrees with Mistress Page’s suggestion to trick Falstaff, and sees how this may help her cure Ford’s jealousy. She sets herself up as the main bait to the fat knight, and acts her role very convincingly. Though her husband is quick to question her fidelity, he trusts her enough to leave her in charge of the family finances — the main source of Falstaff’s attraction to her.

Mistress Margaret Page is a middle-aged lady of Windsor who is fond of her husband George, though she has rather different ideas about who should marry their daughter Anne. She is astounded and infuriated to suddenly be wooed by Falstaff, feelings that grow when she discovers that her friend Mistress Ford has received exactly the same love letter she has. She immediately thinks of causing him mischief, and also sees there an opportunity of helping Mistress Ford overcome her husband’s manic jealousy. An imaginative woman, she is well-respected by all; she is also concerned for her son William’s education. She is excellent at playing a role, but does not consider that she may have passed this talent on to her daughter, and is therefore taken by surprise when Anne manages to escape and marry the man she wishes rather than the upper-class French Doctor her mother prefers. Mistress Page is trusted and loved by her husband, and is in charge of the family finances — the main source of Falstaff’s attraction to her.

Anne Page is the daughter of Master George Page and Mistress Margaret. A lovely brown-haired girl of marriageable age, she is not enthusiastic about either of her parents’ choices for her husband, though she hopes to get their approval for Master Fenton, whom she prefers. She is rather more intelligent than her suitor Slender, whom she has to put up with because of her father, and has no taste for the French Caius. In the end she is willing to deceive both her parents and the suitors in order to run off with Fenton.

Mistress Quickly is Dr. Caius’s housekeeper, a foolish woman with a poor command of language, mixing up her English words and unable to identify Latin as a foreign language as opposed to dirty English. As she knows Anne Page, she acts as a go-between for all of her suitors, encouraging all of them and taking credit for any success they have, as she herself has no particular opinion as to which one should gain Anne so long as she gets paid. Mistress Quickly is also used as a go-between by Mistress Page and Mistress Ford to Falstaff, something that makes Pistol realize that she has her value and is worth pursuing. Despite her problems with English, she is able to learn enough good language to play the Queen of the Fairies in the final prank on Falstaff.

persname.short: SLEN., ALL PAGE. AND SHAL. AND SLEN.

persona.persdescription: Master Abraham Slender is Justice Shallow’s nephew, a rich and foolish man who wishes to marry Anne Page. Far from being the brightest, he keeps a notebook with good lines to use on women, but forgets to bring it with him and is left dependent on his uncle’s promptings to try and woo Anne, with limited success. He relies on Shallow for almost everything, and it is his misfortune that his uncle is not much brighter than he is himself. He agrees with Page’s suggestion that he run off with Anne during the final prank on Falstaff, but never considers that she might trick him. Blond and tall, he has a weak face and a small beard, and struts when he walks.

The First Servant (John) works for the Fords, and removes the rather heavy laundry-basket containing Falstaff at his mistress’ order and dumps its contents in the ditch. He is hopeful that this will not become a regular occurrence.

The Second Servant (Robert) works for the Fords, and removes the rather heavy laundry-basket containing Falstaff at his mistress’ order and dumps its contents in the ditch. He is hopeful that this will not become a regular occurrence.
Children of Windsor [mute roles] are Evans’s students, whom he trains to play fairies in the final prank on Falstaff.

The Postmaster’s Boy [mute role] is one of Evans’s students, who plays a fairy in the final prank on Falstaff. He is always part of the plot to let Anne elope with Fenton. He dresses in white and learns the code words that Slender has arranged, and goes off with him. As he is masked, Slender does not discover his mistake until they are in church.

A Boy [mute role] is one of Evans’s students, who plays a fairy in the final prank on Falstaff. He is always part of the plot to let Anne elope with Fenton. Masked and dressed in green, he runs off with Dr. Caius, who does not discover that he is not Anne until after a marriage ceremony is performed.

scene.scenepersonae: (Justice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Evans, Page, Falstaff, Bardolph, Nym, Pistol, Anne Page, Mistress Ford, Mistress Page, Simple)
scene.stagedir: Enter Justice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Evans.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir Hugh, persuade me not; I will make a Star Chamber matter of it. If he were twenty Sir John Falstaffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow, esquire.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: In the county of Gloucester, Justice of Peace and Coram.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ay, cousin Slender, and Custa-lorum.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, and Rato-lorum too; and a gentleman born, Master Parson, who writes himself Armigero, in any bill, warrant, quittance, or obligation, Armigero.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ay, that I do, and have done any time these three hundred years.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: All his successors (gone before him) hath done’t; and all his ancestors (that come after him) may. They may give the dozen white luces in their coat.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: It is an old coat.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: The dozen white louses do become an old coat well; it agrees well, passant. It is a familiar beast to man, and signifies love.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: The luce is the fresh fish, the salt fish is an old coat.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I may quarter, coz.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: You may, by marrying.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Not a whit.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Yes, py’r lady. If he has a quarter of your coat, there is but three skirts for yourself, in my simple conjectures. But that is all one. If Sir John Falstaff have committed disparagements unto you, I am of the church, and will be glad to do my benevolence to make atonements and compremises between you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: The Council shall hear it, it is a riot.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is not meet the Council hear a riot; there is no fear of Got in a riot. The Council, look you, shall desire to hear the fear of Got, and not to hear a riot. Take your vizaments in that.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha! O’ my life, if I were young again, the sword should end it.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is petter that friends is the sword, and end it; and there is also another device in my prain, which peradventure prings goot discretions with it: there is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master George Page, which is pretty virginity.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Mistress Anne Page? She has brown hair, and speaks small like a woman.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is that fery person for all the orld, as just as you will desire, and seven hundred pounds of moneys, and gold, and silver, is her grandsire upon his death’s-bed (Got deliver to a joyful resurrections!) give, when she is able to overtake seventeen years old. It were a goot motion if we leave our pribbles and prabbles, and desire a marriage between Master Abraham and Mistress Anne Page.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Did her grandsire leave her seven hundred pound?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Ay, and her father is make her a petter penny.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I know the young gentlewoman, she has good gifts.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Seven hundred pounds, and possibilities, is goot gifts.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Well, let us see honest Master Page. Is Falstaff there?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Shall I tell you a lie? I do despise a liar as I do despise one that is false, or as I despise one that is not true. The knight Sir John is there, and I beseech you be rul’d by your well-willers. I will peat the door for Master Page.
What ho! Got pless your house here!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Here is Got’s plessing, and your friend, and Justice Shallow, and here young Master Slender, that peradventures shall tell you another tale, if matters grow to your likings.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I am glad to see your worships well. I thank you for my venison, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Master Page, I am glad to see you. Much good do it your good heart! I wish’d your venison better, it was ill kill’d. How doth good Mistress Page?—and I thank you always with my heart, la! With my heart.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir, I thank you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: How does your fallow greyhound, sir? I heard say he was outrun on Cotsall.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: It could not be judg’d, sir.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: You’ll not confess, You’ll not confess.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: That he will not. ’Tis your fault, ’tis your fault; ’tis a good dog.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: A cur, sir.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir! He’s a good dog, and a fair dog—can there be more said? He is good, and fair. Is Sir John Falstaff here?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a good office between you.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: He hath wrong’d me, Master Page.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: If it be confess’d, it is not redress’d. Is not that so, Master Page? He hath wrong’d me, indeed he hath, at a word he hath. Believe me, Robert Shallow, esquire, saith he is wrong’d.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Here comes Sir John.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sir John Falstaff, Bardolph, Nym, Pistol.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Now, Master Shallow, You’ll complain of me to the King?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Knight, you have beaten my men, kill’d my deer, and broke open my lodge.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: But not kiss’d your keeper’s daughter?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Tut, a pin! This shall be answer’d.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I will answer it straight: I have done all this. That is now answer’d.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: The Council shall know this.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Twere better for you if it were known in counsel. You’ll be laugh’d at.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Pauca verba; Sir John, good worts.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Good worts? Good cabbage. Slender, I broke your head; what matter have you against me?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Marry, sir, I have matter in my head against you, and against your cony-catching rascals, Bardolph, Nym, and Pistol. They carried me to the tavern and made me drunk, and afterward pick’d my pocket.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: You Banbury cheese!

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, it is no matter.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: How now, Mephostophilus?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, it is no matter.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: Slice, I say! Pauca, pauca. Slice, that’s my humor.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Where’s Simple, my man? Can you tell, cousin?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Peace, I pray you. Now let us understand. There is three umpires in this matter, as I understand: that is, Master Page (fidelicet Master Page) and there is myself (fidelicet myself) and the three party is (lastly and finally) mine host of the Garter.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: We three to hear it and end it between them.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Fery goot. I will make a prief of it in my note-book, and we will afterwards ork upon the cause with as great discreetly as we can.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Pistol!

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: He hears with ears.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: The tevil and his tam! What phrase is this? “He hears with ear”? Why, it is affectations.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Pistol, did you pick Master Slender’s purse?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, by these gloves, did he, or I would I might never come in mine own great chamber again else, of seven groats in mill-sixpences, and two Edward shovel-boards, that cost me two shilling and two pence a-piece of Yead Miller—by these gloves.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Is this true, Pistol?

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: No, it is false, if it is a pick-purse.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Ha, thou mountain-foreigner! Sir John, and master mine,
I combat challenge of this latten bilbo.
Word of denial in thy labras here!
Word of denial! Froth and scum, thou liest!

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: By these gloves, then ’twas he.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: Be avis’d, sir, and pass good humors. I will say “marry trap” with you, if you run the nuthook’s humor on me—that is the very note of it.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: By this hat, then he in the red face had it; for though I cannot remember what I did when you made me drunk, yet I am not altogether an ass.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What say you, Scarlet and John?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Why, sir, for my part, I say the gentleman had drunk himself out of his five sentences.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is his five senses. Fie, what the ignorance is!

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: And being fap, sir, was (as they say) cashier’d; and so conclusions pass’d the careers.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, you spake in Latin then too: but ’tis no matter; I’ll ne’er be drunk whilst I live again, but in honest, civil, godly company, for this trick. If I be drunk, I’ll be drunk with those that have the fear of God, and not with drunken knaves.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: So Got udge me, that is a virtuous mind.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You hear all these matters denied, gentlemen; you hear it.

scene.stagedir: Enter Anne Page with wine, Mistress Ford, Mistress Page.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Nay, daughter, carry the wine in, we’ll drink within.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: O heaven! This is Mistress Anne Page.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: How now, Mistress Ford?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Mistress Ford, by my troth, you are very well met. By your leave, good mistress.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome. Come, we have a hot venison pasty to dinner. Come, gentlemen, I hope we shall drink down all unkindness.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt all except Shallow, Slender, and Evans.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I had rather than forty shillings I had my Book of Songs and Sonnets here.
How now, Simple, where have you been? I must wait on myself, must I? You have not the Book of Riddles about you, have you?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Book of Riddles? Why, did you not lend it to Alice Shortcake upon All-hallowmas last, a fortnight afore Michaelmas?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Come, coz, come, coz, we stay for you. A word with you, coz; marry, this, coz: there is as ’twere a tender, a kind of tender, made afar off by Sir Hugh here. Do you understand me?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, sir, you shall find me reasonable. If it be so, I shall do that that is reason.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Nay, but understand me.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: So I do, sir.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Give ear to his motions: Master Slender, I will description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Nay, I will do as my cousin Shallow says. I pray you pardon me; he’s a Justice of Peace in his country, simple though I stand here.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: But that is not the question: the question is concerning your marriage.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ay, there’s the point, sir.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Marry, is it; the very point of it—to Mistress Anne Page.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Why, if it be so, I will marry her upon any reasonable demands.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: But can you affection the oman? Let us command to know that of your mouth, or of your lips; for divers philosophers hold that the lips is parcel of the mouth. Therefore precisely, can you carry your good will to the maid?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I hope, sir, I will do as it shall become one that would do reason.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Nay, Got’s lords and his ladies, you must speak possitable, if you can carry her your desires towards her.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: That you must. Will you, upon good dowry, marry her?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I will do a greater thing than that, upon your request, cousin, in any reason.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Nay, conceive me, conceive me, sweet coz; what I do is to pleasure you, coz. Can you love the maid?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I will marry her, sir, at your request; but if there be no great love in the beginning, yet heaven may decrease it upon better acquaintance, when we are married and have more occasion to know one another. I hope, upon familiarity will grow more content. But if you say, “Marry her,” I will marry her; that I am freely dissolv’d, and dissolutely.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: It is a fery discretion answer, save the fall is in the ord “dissolutely.” The ort is (according to our meaning) “resolutely.” His meaning is good.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ay—I think my cousin meant well.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Ay, or else I would I might be hang’d, la!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Here comes fair Mistress Anne.
Would I were young for your sake, Mistress Anne!

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: The dinner is on the table. My father desires your worships’ company.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: I will wait on him, fair Mistress Anne.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: ’Od’s plessed will! I will not be absence at the grace.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Will’t please your worship to come in, sir?

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: No, I thank you, forsooth, heartily; I am very well.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: The dinner attends you, sir.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I am not a-hungry, I thank you, forsooth. Go, sirrah, for all you are my man, go wait upon my cousin Shallow.
A Justice of Peace sometime may be beholding to his friend for a man. I keep but three men and a boy yet, till my mother be dead. But what though? Yet I live like a poor gentleman born.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I may not go in without your worship; they will not sit till you come.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I’ faith, I’ll eat nothing. I thank you as much as though I did.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, walk in.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I had rather walk here, I thank you. I bruis’d my shin th’ other day with playing at sword and dagger with a master of fence (three veneys for a dish of stew’d prunes) and by my troth, I cannot abide the smell of hot meat since. Why do your dogs bark so? Be there bears i’ th’ town?

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I think there are, sir, I heard them talk’d of.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I love the sport well, but I shall as soon quarrel at it as any man in England. You are afraid if you see the bear loose, are you not?

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Ay indeed, sir.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: That’s meat and drink to me, now. I have seen Sackerson loose twenty times, and have taken him by the chain; but (I warrant you) the women have so cried and shriek’d at it, that it pass’d. But women, indeed, cannot abide ’em, they are very ill-favor’d rough things.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Come, gentle Master Slender, come; we stay for you.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I’ll eat nothing, I thank you, sir.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: By cock and pie, you shall not choose, sir! Come, come.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Nay, pray you lead the way.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Come on, sir.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Mistress Anne, yourself shall go first.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Not I, sir, pray you keep on.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Truly I will not go first; truly la! I will not do you that wrong.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I pray you, sir.

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: I’ll rather be unmannerly than troublesome. You do yourself wrong indeed la!

scene.scenepersonae: (Evans, Simple)
scene.stagedir: Enter Evans and Simple from dinner.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Go your ways, and ask of Doctor Caius’ house which is the way; and there dwells one Mistress Quickly, which is in the manner of his nurse—or his dry nurse—or his cook—or his laundry—his washer and his wringer.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Well, sir.

speech.speaker: EVANS.
speech.line: Nay, it is petter yet. Give her this letter; for it is a oman that altogether’s acquaintance with Mistress Anne Page; and the letter is to desire and require her to solicit your master’s desires to Mistress Anne Page. I pray you be gone. I will make an end of my dinner; there’s pippins and cheese to come.

scene.scenelocation: A room in the Garter Inn.
scene.scenepersonae: (Falstaff, Host, Bardolph, Nym, Pistol, Robin)
scene.stagedir: Enter Falstaff, Host, Bardolph, Nym, Pistol, Robin, Falstaff’s page.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Mine host of the Garter!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: What says my bully-rook? Speak scholarly and wisely.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Truly, mine host, I must turn away some of my followers.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Discard, bully Hercules, cashier; let them wag; trot, trot.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I sit at ten pounds a week.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Thou’rt an emperor—Caesar, Keiser, and Pheazar. I will entertain Bardolph; he shall draw, he shall tap. Said I well, bully Hector?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Do so, good mine host.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: I have spoke; let him follow.
Let me see thee froth and lime. I am at a word; follow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Bardolph, follow him. A tapster is a good trade. An old cloak makes a new jerkin; a wither’d servingman a fresh tapster. Go, adieu.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: It is a life that I have desir’d. I will thrive.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: O base Hungarian wight! Wilt thou the spigot wield?

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: He was gotten in drink. Is not the humor conceited?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am glad I am so acquit of this tinderbox; his thefts were too open; his filching was like an unskillful singer, he kept not time.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: The good humor is to steal at a minute’s rest.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: “Convey,” the wise it call. “Steal”? Foh! A fico for the phrase!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, sirs, I am almost out at heels.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Why then let kibes ensue.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: There is no remedy; I must cony-catch, I must shift.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Young ravens must have food.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Which of you know Ford of this town?

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I ken the wight; he is of substance good.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My honest lads, I will tell you what I am about.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Two yards, and more.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No quips now, Pistol! Indeed I am in the waist two yards about; but I am now about no waste; I am about thrift. Briefly—I do mean to make love to Ford’s wife. I spy entertainment in her. She discourses, she carves, she gives the leer of invitation. I can construe the action of her familiar style, and the hardest voice of her behavior (to be English’d rightly) is, “I am Sir John Falstaff’s.”

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: He hath studied her well, and translated her will, out of honesty into English.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: The anchor is deep. Will that humor pass?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Now, the report goes she has all the rule of her husband’s purse. He hath a legend of angels.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: As many devils entertain; and “To her, boy,” say I.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: The humor rises; it is good. Humor me the angels.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I have writ me here a letter to her; and here another to Page’s wife, who even now gave me good eyes too, examin’d my parts with most judicious iliads; sometimes the beam of her view gilded my foot, sometimes my portly belly.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Then did the sun on dunghill shine.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: I thank thee for that humor.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: O, she did so course o’er my exteriors with such a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye did seem to scorch me up like a burning-glass! Here’s another letter to her. She bears the purse too; she is a region in Guiana, all gold and bounty. I will be cheaters to them both, and they shall be exchequers to me. They shall be my East and West Indies, and I will trade to them both. Go, bear thou this letter to Mistress Page; and thou this to Mistress Ford. We will thrive, lads, we will thrive.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side wear steel? Then Lucifer take all!

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: I will run no base humor. Here, take the humor-letter; I will keep the havior of reputation.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Hold, sirrah, bear you these letters tightly;
Sail like my pinnace to these golden shores.
Rogues, hence, avaunt, vanish like hailstones; go!
Trudge! Plod away i’ th’ hoof! Seek shelter, pack!
Falstaff will learn the humor of the age,
French thrift, you rogues—myself and skirted page.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Let vultures gripe thy guts! For gourd and fullam holds,
And high and low beguiles the rich and poor.
Tester I’ll have in pouch when thou shalt lack,
Base Phrygian Turk!

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: I have operations in my head which be humors of revenge.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Wilt thou revenge?

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: By welkin and her star!

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: With wit or steel?

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: With both the humors, I.
I will discuss the humor of this love to Page.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: And I to Ford shall eke unfold
How Falstaff (varlet vile)
His dove will prove, his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: My humor shall not cool. I will incense Page to deal with poison; I will possess him with yallowness, for the revolt of mine is dangerous—that is my true humor.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Thou art the Mars of malecontents. I second thee; troop on.

scene.scenelocation: A room in Doctor Caius’ house.
scene.scenepersonae: (Mistress Quickly, Simple, John Rugby, Doctor Caius, Fenton)

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: What, John Rugby!

I pray thee go to the casement, and see if you can see my master, Master Doctor Caius, coming. If he do, i’ faith, and find any body in the house, here will be an old abusing of God’s patience and the King’s English.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: I’ll go watch.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Go, and we’ll have a posset for’t soon at night, in faith, at the latter end of a sea-coal fire.

An honest, willing, kind fellow as ever servant shall come in house withal; and I warrant you, no tell-tale nor no breed-bate. His worst fault is, that he is given to prayer; he is something peevish that way; but nobody but has his fault—but let that pass. Peter Simple, you say your name is?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Ay, for fault of a better.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: And Master Slender’s your master?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Ay, forsooth.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Does he not wear a great round beard, like a glover’s paring-knife?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: No, forsooth; he hath but a little whey-face, with a little yellow beard, a Cain-color’d beard.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: A softly-sprighted man, is he not?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Ay, forsooth; but he is as tall a man of his hands as any is between this and his head. He hath fought with a warrener.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: How say you? O, I should remember him. Does he not hold up his head (as it were) and strut in his gait?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Yes indeed does he.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Well, heaven send Anne Page no worse fortune! Tell Master Parson Evans I will do what I can for your master. Anne is a good girl, and I wish—

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Out alas! Here comes my master.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: We shall all be shent. Run in here, good young man; go into this closet. He will not stay long.
What, John Rugby! John! What, John, I say! Go, John, go inquire for my master; I doubt he be not well, that he comes not home.
And down, down, adown-a, etc.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Vat is you sing? I do not like des toys. Pray you go and vetch me in my closet une boÎte en verd, a box, a green-a box. Do intend vat I speak? A green-a box.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Ay, forsooth, I’ll fetch it you.
I am glad he went not in himself; if he had found the young man, he would have been horn-mad.

line.french: Fe, fe, fe, fe! Ma foi, il fait fort chaud. O, je m’en vois à la cour—la grande affaire.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Is it this, sir?

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Oui, mette le au mon pocket; dépêche, quickly. Vere is dat knave Rugby?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: What, John Rugby! John!

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Here, sir!

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: You are John Rugby, and you are Jack Rugby. Come, take-a your rapier, and come after my heel to the court.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: ’Tis ready, sir, here in the porch.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By my trot, I tarry too long. ’Od’s me! Qu’ai-je oublié? Dere is some simples in my closet, dat I vill not for the varld I shall leave behind.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Ay me, he’ll find the young man there, and be mad!

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: O diable, diable! Vat is in my closet? Villainy! Laroon!
Rugby, my rapier!

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Good master, be content.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Wherefore shall I be content-a?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: The young man is an honest man.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: What shall de honest man do in my closet? Dere is no honest man dat shall come in my closet.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: I beseech you be not so phlegmatic. Hear the truth of it: he came of an errand to me from Parson Hugh.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Vell?

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: Ay, forsooth; to desire her to—

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Peace, I pray you.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Peace-a your tongue.—Speak-a your tale.

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: To desire this honest gentlewoman, your maid, to speak a good word to Mistress Anne Page for my master in the way of marriage.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: This is all indeed la! But I’ll ne’er put my finger in the fire, and need not.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Sir Hugh send-a you? Rugby, baillez me some paper. Tarry you a little-a while.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: I am glad he is so quiet. If he had been throughly mov’d, you should have heard him so loud and so melancholy. But notwithstanding, man, I’ll do you your master what good I can; and the very yea and the no is, the French doctor, my master (I may call him my master, look you, for I keep his house; and I wash, wring, brew, bake, scour, dress meat and drink, make the beds, and do all myself)—

speech.speaker: SIM.
speech.line: ’Tis a great charge to come under one body’s hand.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Are you avis’d o’ that? You shall find it a great charge; and to be up early and down late; but notwithstanding (to tell you in your ear, I would have no words of it) my master himself is in love with Mistress Anne Page; but notwithstanding that, I know Anne’s mind—that’s neither here nor there.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: You jack’nape, give-a this letter to Sir Hugh. By gar, it is a shallenge. I will cut his troat in de park; and I will teach a scurvy jack-a-nape priest to meddle or make—You may be gone; it is not good you tarry here. By gar, I will cut all his two stones; by gar, he shall not have a stone to throw at his dog.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Alas! He speaks but for his friend.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: It is no matter-a ver dat. Do not you tell-a me dat I shall have Anne Page for myself? By gar, I vill kill de Jack priest; and I have appointed mine host of de Jarteer to measure our weapon. By gar, I will myself have Anne Page.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Sir, the maid loves you, and all shall be well. We must give folks leave to prate; what the good-jer!

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Rugby, come to the court with me. By gar, if I have not Anne Page, I shall turn your head out of my door. Follow my heels, Rugby.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: You shall have Anne—fool’s-head of your own. No, I know Anne’s mind for that. Never a woman in Windsor knows more of Anne’s mind than I do, nor can do more than I do with her, I thank heaven.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Who’s within there, ho?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Who’s there, I trow? Come near the house, I pray you.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: How now, good woman, how dost thou?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: The better that it pleases your good worship to ask.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: What news? How does pretty Mistress Anne?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: In truth, sir, and she is pretty, and honest, and gentle, and one that is your friend; I can tell you that by the way, I praise heaven for it.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Shall I do any good, think’st thou? Shall I not lose my suit?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Troth, sir, all is in His hands above. But notwithstanding, Master Fenton, I’ll be sworn on a book she loves you. Have not your worship a wart above your eye?

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Yes, marry, have I, what of that?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Well, thereby hangs a tale. Good faith, it is such another Nan; but (I detest) an honest maid as ever broke bread. We had an hour’s talk of that wart. I shall never laugh but in that maid’s company! But, indeed, she is given too much to allicholy and musing; but for you—well—go to.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Well; I shall see her today. Hold, there’s money for thee. Let me have thy voice in my behalf. If thou seest her before me, commend me.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Will I? I’ faith, that we will; and I will tell your worship more of the wart the next time we have confidence, and of other wooers.

speech.speaker: FENT.
speech.line: Well, farewell, I am in great haste now.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Farewell to your worship.
Truly, an honest gentleman; but Anne loves him not; for I know Anne’s mind as well as another does. Out upon’t! What have I forgot?

scene.scenepersonae: (Mistress Page, Mistress Ford, Ford, Pistol, Page, Nym, Mistress Quickly, Host, Shallow)
scene.stagedir: Enter Mistress Page, reading of a letter.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: What, have I scap’d love-letters in the holiday-time of my beauty, and am I now a subject for them? Let me see.

line.RECITE: “Ask me no reason why I love you, for though Love use Reason for his precisian, he admits him not for his counsellor. You are not young, no more am I; go to then, there’s sympathy. You are merry, so am I; ha, ha! Then there’s more sympathy. You love sack, and so do I; would you desire better sympathy? Let it suffice thee, Mistress Page—at the least if the love of a soldier can suffice—that I love thee. I will not say, pity me—’tis not a soldier-like phrase—but I say, love me. By me,

speech.line: What a Herod of Jewry is this! O wicked, wicked world! One that is well-nigh worn to pieces with age to show himself a young gallant! What an unweigh’d behavior hath this Flemish drunkard pick’d (with the devil’s name!) out of my conversation, that he dares in this manner assay me? Why, he hath not been thrice in my company! What should I say to him? I was then frugal of my mirth. Heaven forgive me! Why, I’ll exhibit a bill in the parliament for the putting down of men. How shall I be reveng’d on him? For reveng’d I will be! As sure as his guts are made of puddings.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Mistress Page, trust me, I was going to your house.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: And trust me, I was coming to you. You look very ill.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll ne’er believe that; I have to show to the contrary.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Faith, but you do, in my mind.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Well—I do then; yet I say I could show you to the contrary. O Mistress Page, give me some counsel!

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: What’s the matter, woman?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: O woman—if it were not for one trifling respect, I could come to such honor!

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Hang the trifle, woman, take the honor. What is it? Dispense with trifles. What is it?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: If I would but go to hell for an eternal moment or so, I could be knighted.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: What? Thou liest! Sir Alice Ford! These knights will hack, and so thou shouldst not alter the article of thy gentry.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: We burn daylight. Here, read, read; perceive how I might be knighted. I shall think the worse of fat men, as long as I have an eye to make difference of men’s liking: and yet he would not swear; prais’d women’s modesty; and gave such orderly and well-behav’d reproof to all uncomeliness, that I would have sworn his disposition would have gone to the truth of his words; but they do no more adhere and keep place together than the hundred Psalms to the tune of “Green-sleeves.” What tempest, I trow, threw this whale (with so many tuns of oil in his belly) ashore at Windsor? How shall I be reveng’d on him? I think the best way were to entertain him with hope, till the wicked fire of lust have melted him in his own grease. Did you ever hear the like?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Letter for letter; but that the name of Page and Ford differs! To thy great comfort in this mystery of ill opinions, here’s the twin-brother of thy letter; but let thine inherit first, for I protest mine never shall. I warrant he hath a thousand of these letters, writ with blank space for different names (sure, more!); and these are of the second edition. He will print them, out of doubt; for he cares not what he puts into the press, when he would put us two. I had rather be a giantess, and lie under Mount Pelion. Well—I will find you twenty lascivious turtles ere one chaste man.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Why, this is the very same: the very hand; the very words. What doth he think of us?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Nay, I know not; it makes me almost ready to wrangle with mine own honesty. I’ll entertain myself like one that I am not acquainted withal; for sure unless he know some strain in me that I know not myself, he would never have boarded me in this fury.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: “Boarding,” call you it? I’ll be sure to keep him above deck.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: So will I; if he come under my hatches, I’ll never to sea again. Let’s be reveng’d on him: let’s appoint him a meeting, give him a show of comfort in his suit, and lead him on with a fine-baited delay, till he hath pawn’d his horses to mine host of the Garter.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Nay, I will consent to act any villainy against him, that may not sully the chariness of our honesty. O that my husband saw this letter! It would give eternal food to his jealousy.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Why, look where he comes; and my good man too. He’s as far from jealousy as I am from giving him cause, and that (I hope) is an unmeasurable distance.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: You are the happier woman.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Let’s consult together against this greasy knight. Come hither.

scene.stagedir: Enter Ford with Pistol; Page with Nym.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Well, I hope it be not so.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Hope is a curtal dog in some affairs. Sir John affects thy wife.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Why, sir, my wife is not young.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: He woos both high and low, both rich and poor,
Both young and old, one with another, Ford.
He loves the gallimaufry, Ford. Perpend.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Love my wife?

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: With liver burning hot. Prevent; or go thou
Like Sir Actaeon he, with Ringwood at thy heels—
O, odious is the name!

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: What name, sir?

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: The horn, I say. Farewell.
Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night.
Take heed, ere summer comes or cuckoo-birds do sing.
Away, Sir Corporal Nym!
Believe it, Page, he speaks sense.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I will be patient; I will find out this.

speech.speaker: NYM.
speech.line: And this is true; I like not the humor of lying. He hath wrong’d me in some humors. I should have borne the humor’d letter to her; but I have a sword, and it shall bite upon my necessity. He loves your wife: there’s the short and the long. My name is Corporal Nym; I speak, and I avouch; ’tis true; my name is Nym, and Falstaff loves your wife. Adieu. I love not the humor of bread and cheese and there’s the humor of it. Adieu.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: “The humor of it,” quoth ’a! Here’s a fellow frights English out of his wits.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I will seek out Falstaff.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I never heard such a drawling, affecting rogue.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: If I do find it—well.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I will not believe such a Cataian, though the priest o’ th’ town commended him for a true man.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: ’Twas a good sensible fellow—well.

scene.stagedir: Mrs. Page and Mrs. Ford come forward.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: How now, Meg?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Whither go you, George, hark you?

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: How now, sweet Frank, why art thou melancholy?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I melancholy? I am not melancholy. Get you home; go.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Faith, thou hast some crotchets in thy head now. Will you go, Mistress Page?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Have with you. You’ll come to dinner, George?
Look who comes yonder. She shall be our messenger to this paltry knight.

speech.speaker: MRS. FORD.
speech.line: Trust me, I thought on her. She’ll fit it.

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: You are come to see my daughter Anne?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Ay, forsooth; and I pray, how does good Mistress Anne?

speech.speaker: MRS. PAGE.
speech.line: Go in with us and see. We have an hour’s talk with you.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Mrs. Page, Mrs. Ford, and Mrs. Quickly.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: How now, Master Ford?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: You heard what this knave told me, did you not?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Do you think there is truth in them?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Hang ’em, slaves! I do not think the knight would offer it; but these that accuse him in his intent towards our wives are a yoke of his discarded men—very rogues, now they be out of service.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Were they his men?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Marry, were they.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I like it never the better for that. Does he lie at the Garter?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Ay, marry, does he. If he should intend this voyage toward my wife, I would turn her loose to him; and what he gets more of her than sharp words, let it lie on my head.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I do not misdoubt my wife; but I would be loath to turn them together. A man may be too confident. I would have nothing lie on my head. I cannot be thus satisfied.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Look where my ranting host of the Garter comes. There is either liquor in his pate, or money in his purse, when he looks so merrily. How now, mine host?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: How now, bully-rook? Thou’rt a gentleman. Cavaleiro Justice, I say!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: I follow, mine host, I follow. Good even and twenty, good Master Page! Master Page, will you go with us? We have sport in hand.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Tell him, Cavaleiro Justice; tell him, bully-rook.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir, there is a fray to be fought between Sir Hugh the Welsh priest and Caius the French doctor.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Good mine host o’ th’ Garter, a word with you.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: What say’st thou, my bully-rook?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Will you go with us to behold it? My merry host hath had the measuring of their weapons, and, I think, hath appointed them contrary places; for, believe me, I hear the parson is no jester. Hark, I will tell you what our sport shall be.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Hast thou no suit against my knight, my guest-cavalier?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: None, I protest; but I’ll give you a pottle of burnt sack to give me recourse to him and tell him my name is Brook—only for a jest.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: My hand, bully; thou shalt have egress and regress—said I well?—and thy name shall be Brook. It is a merry knight. Will you go, An-heires?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Have with you, mine host.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: I have heard the Frenchman hath good skill in his rapier.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Tut, sir; I could have told you more. In these times you stand on distance: your passes, stoccadoes, and I know not what. ’Tis the heart, Master Page, ’tis here, ’tis here. I have seen the time, with my long sword I would have made you four tall fellows skip like rats.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Here, boys, here, here! Shall we wag?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Have with you. I had rather hear them scold than fight.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Though Page be a secure fool, and stands so firmly on his wife’s frailty, yet I cannot put off my opinion so easily. She was in his company at Page’s house; and what they made there, I know not. Well, I will look further into’t, and I have a disguise to sound Falstaff. If I find her honest, I lose not my labor; if she be otherwise, ’tis labor well bestow’d.

scene.scenelocation: A room in the Garter Inn.
scene.scenepersonae: (Falstaff, Pistol, Robin, Mistress Quickly, Bardolph, Ford)

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I will retort the sum in equipage.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I will not lend thee a penny.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Why then the world’s mine oyster,
Which I with sword will open.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Not a penny. I have been content, sir, you should lay my countenance to pawn. I have grated upon my good friends for three reprieves for you and your coach-fellow Nym; or else you had look’d through the grate, like a geminy of baboons. I am damn’d in hell for swearing to gentlemen my friends, you were good soldiers and tall fellows; and when Mistress Bridget lost the handle of her fan, I took’t upon mine honor thou hadst it not.

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: Didst not thou share? Hadst thou not fifteen pence?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Reason, you rogue, reason; think’st thou I’ll endanger my soul gratis? At a word, hang no more about me, I am no gibbet for you. Go—a short knife and a throng!—to your manor of Pickt-hatch! Go. You’ll not bear a letter for me, you rogue? You stand upon your honor! Why, thou unconfinable baseness, it is as much as I can do to keep the terms of my honor precise. I, I, I myself sometimes, leaving the fear of God on the left hand, and hiding mine honor in my necessity, am fain to shuffle, to hedge, and to lurch; and yet you, rogue, will ensconce your rags, your cat-a-mountain looks, your red-lattice phrases, and your bold-beating oaths, under the shelter of your honor! You will not do it? You!

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: I do relent. What would thou more of man?

speech.speaker: ROB.
speech.line: Sir, here’s a woman would speak with you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let her approach.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Give your worship good morrow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Good morrow, goodwife.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Not so, and’t please your worship.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Good maid then.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: I’ll be sworn,
As my mother was the first hour I was born.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I do believe the swearer. What with me?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Shall I vouchsafe your worship a word or two?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Two thousand, fair woman, and I’ll vouchsafe thee the hearing.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: There is one Mistress Ford, sir—I pray come a little nearer this ways. I myself dwell with Master Doctor Caius—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, on. Mistress Ford, you say—

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Your worship says very true. I pray your worship come a little nearer this ways.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I warrant thee, nobody hears—mine own people, mine own people.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Are they so? God bless them and make them his servants!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well; Mistress Ford, what of her?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Why, sir, she’s a good creature. Lord, Lord, your worship’s a wanton! Well—heaven forgive you, and all of us, I pray—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Mistress Ford; come, Mistress Ford—

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Marry, this is the short and the long of it: you have brought her into such a canaries as ’tis wonderful. The best courtier of them all (when the court lay at Windsor) could never have brought her to such a canary; yet there has been knights, and lords, and gentlemen, with their coaches; I warrant you, coach after coach, letter after letter, gift after gift; smelling so sweetly, all musk, and so rushling, I warrant you, in silk and gold, and in such alligant terms, and in such wine and sugar of the best, and the fairest, that would have won any woman’s heart; and I warrant you, they could never get an eye-wink of her. I had myself twenty angels given me this morning, but I defy all angels (in any such sort, as they say) but in the way of honesty; and I warrant you, they could never get her so much as sip on a cup with the proudest of them all, and yet there has been earls, nay (which is more) pensioners, but I warrant you all is one with her.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: But what says she to me? Be brief, my good she-Mercury.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Marry, she hath receiv’d your letter—for the which she thanks you a thousand times—and she gives you to notify that her husband will be absence from his house between ten and eleven.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ten and eleven?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Ay, forsooth; and then you may come and see the picture, she says, that you wot of. Master Ford her husband will be from home. Alas, the sweet woman leads an ill life with him. He’s a very jealousy man. She leads a very frampold life with him, good heart.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Ten and eleven. Woman, commend me to her, I will not fail her.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Why, you say well. But I have another messenger to your worship. Mistress Page hath her hearty commendations to you too; and let me tell you in your ear, she’s as fartuous a civil modest wife, and one (I tell you) that will not miss you morning nor evening prayer, as any is in Windsor, whoe’er be the other; and she bade me tell your worship that her husband is seldom from home, but she hopes there will come a time. I never knew a woman so dote upon a man; surely I think you have charms, la; yes, in truth.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Not I, I assure thee. Setting the attraction of my good parts aside, I have no other charms.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Blessing on your heart for’t!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: But I pray thee tell me this: has Ford’s wife and Page’s wife acquainted each other how they love me?

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: That were a jest indeed! They have not so little grace, I hope. That were a trick indeed! But Mistress Page would desire you to send her your little page, of all loves. Her husband has a marvellous infection to the little page; and truly Master Page is an honest man. Never a wife in Windsor leads a better life than she does: do what she will, say what she will, take all, pay all, go to bed when she list, rise when she list, all is as she will; and truly she deserves it, for if there be a kind woman in Windsor, she is one. You must send her your page, no remedy.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Why, I will.

speech.speaker: QUICK.
speech.line: Nay, but do so then, and look you, he may come and go between you both; and in any case have a nay-word, that you may know one another’s mind, and the boy never need to understand any thing; for ’tis not good that children should know any wickedness. Old folks, you know, have discretion, as they say, and know the world.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Fare thee well, commend me to them both. There’s my purse, I am yet thy debtor. Boy, go along with this woman.
This news distracts me!

speech.speaker: PIST.
speech.line: This punk is one of Cupid’s carriers.
Clap on more sails, pursue; up with your fights;
Give fire! She is my prize, or ocean whelm them all!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Say’st thou so, old Jack? Go thy ways. I’ll make more of thy old body than I have done. Will they yet look after thee? Wilt thou, after the expense of so much money, be now a gainer? Good body, I thank thee. Let them say ’tis grossly done, so it be fairly done, no matter.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Sir John, there’s one Master Brook below would fain speak with you, and be acquainted with you; and hath sent your worship a morning’s draught of sack.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Brook is his name?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Ay, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Call him in.
Such Brooks are welcome to me, that o’erflows such liquor. Ah, ha! Mistress Ford and Mistress Page, have I encompass’d you? Go to, via!

scene.stagedir: Enter Bardolph with Ford disguised like Brook.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: God save you, sir!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And you, sir! Would you speak with me?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I make bold, to press with so little preparation upon you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You’re welcome. What’s your will? Give us leave, drawer.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Sir, I am a gentleman that have spent much. My name is Brook.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Good Master Brook, I desire more acquaintance of you.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Good Sir John, I sue for yours—not to charge you, for I must let you understand I think myself in better plight for a lender than you are; the which hath something embold’ned me to this unseason’d intrusion; for they say, if money go before, all ways do lie open.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Money is a good soldier, sir, and will on.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Troth, and I have a bag of money here troubles me. If you will help to bear it, Sir John, take all, or half, for easing me of the carriage.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Sir, I know not how I may deserve to be your porter.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I will tell you, sir, if you will give me the hearing.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Speak, good Master Brook, I shall be glad to be your servant.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Sir, I hear you are a scholar (I will be brief with you), and you have been a man long known to me, though I had never so good means as desire to make myself acquainted with you. I shall discover a thing to you, wherein I must very much lay open mine own imperfection; but, good Sir John, as you have one eye upon my follies, as you hear them unfolded, turn another into the register of your own, that I may pass with a reproof the easier, sith you yourself know how easy it is to be such an offender.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Very well, sir, proceed.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: There is a gentlewoman in this town, her husband’s name is Ford.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well, sir.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I have long lov’d her, and I protest to you, bestow’d much on her; follow’d her with a doting observance; engross’d opportunities to meet her; fee’d every slight occasion that could but niggardly give me sight of her; not only bought many presents to give her, but have given largely to many to know what she would have given; briefly, I have pursu’d her as love hath pursu’d me, which hath been on the wing of all occasions. But whatsoever I have merited, either in my mind or in my means, meed I am sure I have receiv’d none, unless experience be a jewel—that I have purchas’d at an infinite rate, and that hath taught me to say this:

line.RECITE: “Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues,
Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.”

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Have you receiv’d no promise of satisfaction at her hands?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Never.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Have you importun’d her to such a purpose?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Never.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Of what quality was your love then?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Like a fair house built on another man’s ground, so that I have lost my edifice by mistaking the place where I erected it.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: To what purpose have you unfolded this to me?

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: When I have told you that, I have told you all. Some say that, though she appear honest to me, yet in other places she enlargeth her mirth so far that there is shrewd construction made of her. Now, Sir John, here is the heart of my purpose: you are a gentleman of excellent breeding, admirable discourse, of great admittance, authentic in your place and person, generally allow’d for your many war-like, court-like, and learned preparations.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: O sir!

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Believe it, for you know it. There is money, spend it, spend it; spend more; spend all I have; only give me so much of your time in exchange of it, as to lay an amiable siege to the honesty of this Ford’s wife. Use your art of wooing; win her to consent to you; if any man may, you may as soon as any.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Would it apply well to the vehemency of your affection, that I should win what you would enjoy? Methinks you prescribe to yourself very preposterously.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: O, understand my drift. She dwells so securely on the excellency of her honor, that the folly of my soul dares not present itself; she is too bright to be look’d against. Now, could I come to her with any detection in my hand, my desires had instance and argument to commend themselves. I could drive her then from the ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage vow, and a thousand other her defenses, which now are too too strongly embattled against me. What say you to’t, Sir John?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Master Brook, I will first make bold with your money; next, give me your hand; and last, as I am a gentleman, you shall, and you will, enjoy Ford’s wife.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: O good sir!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I say you shall.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: Want no money, Sir John, you shall want none.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Want no Mistress Ford, Master Brook, you shall want none. I shall be with her (I may tell you) by her own appointment; even as you came in to me, her assistant or go-between parted from me. I say I shall be with her between ten and eleven; for at that time the jealous rascally knave her husband will be forth. Come you to me at night, you shall know how I speed.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I am blest in your acquaintance. Do you know Ford, sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Hang him, poor cuckoldly knave, I know him not. Yet I wrong him to call him poor. They say the jealous wittolly knave hath masses of money, for the which his wife seems to me well-favor’d. I will use her as the key of the cuckoldly rogue’s coffer, and there’s my harvest-home.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might avoid him if you saw him.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Hang him, mechanical salt-butter rogue! I will stare him out of his wits; I will awe him with my cudgel; it shall hang like a meteor o’er the cuckold’s horns. Master Brook, thou shalt know I will predominate over the peasant, and thou shalt lie with his wife. Come to me soon at night. Ford’s a knave, and I will aggravate his style; thou, Master Brook, shalt know him for knave, and cuckold. Come to me soon at night.

speech.speaker: FORD.
speech.line: What a damn’d Epicurean rascal is this! My heart is ready to crack with impatience. Who says this is improvident jealousy? My wife hath sent to him, the hour is fix’d, the match is made. Would any man have thought this? See the hell of having a false woman! My bed shall be abus’d, my coffers ransack’d, my reputation gnawn at, and I shall not only receive this villainous wrong, but stand under the adoption of abominable terms, and by him that does me this wrong. Terms! Names! Amaimon sounds well; Lucifer, well; Barbason, well; yet they are devils’ additions, the names of fiends; but Cuckold! Wittol!—Cuckold! The devil himself hath not such a name. Page is an ass, a secure ass; he will trust his wife, he will not be jealous. I will rather trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh the Welshman with my cheese, an Irishman with my aqua-vitae bottle, or a thief to walk my ambling gelding, than my wife with herself. Then she plots, then she ruminates, then she devises; and what they think in their hearts they may effect, they will break their hearts but they will effect. God be prais’d for my jealousy! Eleven o’ clock the hour. I will prevent this, detect my wife, be reveng’d on Falstaff, and laugh at Page. I will about it; better three hours too soon than a minute too late. Fie, fie, fie! Cuckold, cuckold, cuckold!

scene.scenepersonae: (Caius, Rugby, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host)

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Jack Rugby!

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Sir?

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Vat is the clock, Jack?

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: ’Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh promis’d to meet.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, he has save his soul, dat he is no come; he has pray his Pible well, dat he is no come. By gar, Jack Rugby, he is dead already, if he be come.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: He is wise, sir; he knew your worship would kill him if he came.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, de herring is no dead so as I vill kill him. Take your rapier, Jack, I vill tell you how I vill kill him.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Alas, sir, I cannot fence.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Villainy, take your rapier.

speech.speaker: RUG.
speech.line: Forbear; here’s company.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: God bless thee, bully-doctor!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: God save you, Master Doctor Caius!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Now, good Master Doctor!

speech.speaker: SLEN.
speech.line: Give you good morrow, sir.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Vat be all you, one, two, tree, four, come for?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to see thee traverse, to see thee here, to see thee there, to see thee pass thy puncto, thy stock, thy reverse, thy distance, thy montant. Is he dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Francisco? Ha, bully? What says my Aesculapius? My Galien? My heart of elder? Ha? Is he dead, bully-stale? Is he dead?

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, he is de coward Jack priest of de vorld; he is not show his face.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Thou art a Castalion-King-Urinal! Hector of Greece, my boy!

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: I pray you bear witness that me have stay six or seven, two, tree hours for him, and he is no come.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: He is the wiser man, Master Doctor: he is a curer of souls, and you a curer of bodies. If you should fight, you go against the hair of your professions. Is it not true, Master Page?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Master Shallow, you have yourself been a great fighter, though now a man of peace.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Bodykins, Master Page, though I now be old and of the peace, if I see a sword out, my finger itches to make one. Though we are justices and doctors and churchmen, Master Page, we have some salt of our youth in us, we are the sons of women, Master Page.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: ’Tis true, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: It will be found so, Master Page. Master Doctor Caius, I am come to fetch you home. I am sworn of the peace. You have show’d yourself a wise physician, and Sir Hugh hath shown himself a wise and patient churchman. You must go with me, Master Doctor.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Pardon, guest-justice. A word, Mounseur Mock-water.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Mock-vater? Vat is dat?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Mock-water, in our English tongue, is valor, bully.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, then I have as much mock-vater as de Englishman. Scurvy Jack-dog priest! By gar, me vill cut his ears.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: He will clapper-claw thee tightly, bully.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Clapper-de-claw? Vat is dat?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: That is, he will make thee amends.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, me do look he shall clapper-de-claw me, for, by gar, me vill have it.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: And I will provoke him to’t, or let him wag.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: Me tank you for dat.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: And moreover, bully—but first, Master Guest, and Master Page, and eke Cavaleiro Slender, go you through the town to Frogmore.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: He is there. See what humor he is in; and I will bring the doctor about by the fields. Will it do well?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: We will do it.

speech.speaker: ALL PAGE. AND SHAL. AND SLEN.)
speech.line: Adieu, good Master Doctor.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt all but the Host, Caius, and Rugby.

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, me vill kill de priest, for he speak for a jack-an-ape to Anne Page.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Let him die; but first sheathe thy impatience, throw cold water on thy choler. Go about the fields with me through Frogmore, I will bring thee where Mistress Anne Page is, at a farm-house a-feasting; and thou shalt woo her. Cried game? Said I well?

speech.speaker: CAIUS.
speech.line: By gar, me dank you vor dat. By gar, I love you; and I shall procure-a you de good guest: de earl, de knight, de lords, de gentlemen, my patients.

speech.speaker: HOST.
